review_title: Great first job, but could be better!
pros: AMAZING benefits! I can even walk in whenever I want to work on my days off and they will always let me work until I want. They have a super flexible schedule and even have a bunch of stuff they give away and the pay is on the good end of jobs in my area for minors. I get fed for free, paid, and work pretty much whenever I want and they can even work around school events/sports. That is why I have stayed working there for almost a year now in April, and it is an amazing first job where I made many friends and learned about my community, and helped with my social anxiety and depression!
cons: The pay could definitely be better and the better pay ($15/hour) is reserved for managers, which you have to be 18 for). They also all pretty much act like middle schoolers with the drama, and the customers and stress can be awful sometimes, but you actually get used to it after the first month or so. There is not really any promotions or raises unless it is mandate by the company.

review_title: Pretty good student job, great confidence booster
pros:
Hours were flexible and relatively easy to change, managers were open to fitting shifts around college and university schedule. 
Pay was better than most alternatives, especially considering jobs that were offering as much flexibility in hours. 
Great for boosting personal confidence in handling customers in various circumstances, helped me gain a more authorative personality as I had been quite shy in the years before this experience.
Staff were in the most part pretty friendly as they were mostly fellow students, managers were generally pretty respectful although they could become irritable during busier than usual periods.
cons:
Customers were often rude, especially during busy periods. While this was something that I found okay to adjust myself to, I did find myself at times feeling stressed by some of the more scathing offenses and at times had to try and mediate situations between colleagues and angry customers.
Sometimes found that managers could throw you out of your depth by getting me to cover positions that I hadn't been properly trained in, this was particularly true during staff shortages and could result in accusations from other staff for slowing down order times as it took time to figure out the most efficient way to carry out these new tasks. 
Heat. It gets hot in the kitchen during summers, our air conditioning system regularly failed or struggled to keep up during the summer months resulting in the kitchen of the restaurant becoming uncomfortably warm, this could result in other staff members becoming stressed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Harbor City, CA
pros: My co-workers were mostly great, and I got along with everyone. My co-workers made the monotonous work hours bearable and sometimes fun. The managerial staff tried to be as accommodating as they could. The work hours were very flexible. Overall not so bad for a minimum wage job.
cons: You have to deal with rude customers. Often equipment kept breaking down, which got annoying at times. When we got new owners, everyone's hours got cut down. So, available work hours vary from week to week. At times, there weren't enough crew members on the floor, which put extra pressure on the skeleton crew. During rush hours, we'd often be spread pretty thin. This made our performance as a team suffer. Depending on which manager was in charge, things would either be working smoothly, or things would be chaotic and disorganized.

job_title: Crew Member in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: To be honest there were not many pros for the restuarant that I worked at, one of the few was that there was one friendly crew member who I could talk to, everybody else was always miserable and mean.
cons:
The managers were unprofessional, there were many crew members who clearly thought they owned the place and treated all the new starters like rubbish.
I never got trained properly they would just tick off my training on the sheets and pretended that they had given me training. It took about 2 months for the managers to listen to me to change my hours when they always said they would deffinitley sort it out for me everytime I asked (they didn't care). One of the managers was always talking rubbish about me and other new starters to the other manager thinking that we couldnt here, when we were literally a couple meatres away. You could tell nobody wanted to be there, there was no positivity even the managers were asking eachother if they could go home early??? Many customers like to treat you like rubbish because you work there, I've had mutliple things thrown at me by customers when i worked there and my manager wouldn't even ban the guy because "It's easier to just leave it alone"?? So I didnt feel safe at work because some guy kept throwing things at me and arguining with me at the window for absolutely no reason other than he probably had a bad day or hated me, they wouldn't even ask him to leave when he kept coming back because they couldn't be bothered. So basically I did get some good patience skills and customer service skills BUT quitting that job was a very good day for me!

review_title: Follow your dreams and GTFO of here
pros:
Experience learning how awful customers and management can be. 
Successfully convinced me to never, ever work in food service again, and instead to apply for my dream job. I got it and now I live overseas doing what I love.
cons: Customers can be really awful, and management being cruel and disrespecting time off that was asked for weeks-months in advance for solid reasons. Shift leads think that they can treat team members whatever way they want with no repercussions, and they're right. Besides Karma and maybe the couple good coworkers you meet, nobody else is looking out for you in this company. Taking food home at closing instead of throwing it directly into a trashcan to be wasted the dump is treated as "theft", regardless of the food insecurity of the coworker was who was "stealing" it. You're quite literally punished for not contributing to food waste. You can never do enough for McDonalds, you have to sell your soul to clean human pee/vomit off the floor with a smile. & the smell of the grill area will never, ever leave your head. Ever.

review_title: Pretty good food, pretty good learning experience!
pros: I learned a lot of skills with it being my first job. I learned how to cook, prepare, and put together menue items, food health and safety, and how to work with people I wouldn't see myself even talking to outside work. I got a free meal and drink for each shift, plus discount on everything there. For every 4 hours of a shift you get a break. Also if people use you as a reference, you get a bonus of $100 for that upcoming paycheck.
cons: There were rumors being tossed about staff members, and a lot of them get irritated by people they share shifts with. It was still a good starting job that I got to work at for a few months.
